PAGE TWO

NEWS-LETTER

Homewood, Baltimore, February 13, 1953

Student - Facu:ty Group To Meet;
Bulletin
Board
Honor System, Other Issues Aired
In order to stimulate more effective discussion of mutual problems, a group of students and
faculty members will meet informally this evening in the Sherwood Room.
"I am hoping that the Honor System will be discussed," Al Epstein, chairman of the student group, said early this week.
Twenty-six persons have been invited to attend; thirteen faculty members and an equal number of "responsible" students.
Epstein reminded that this is the first such meeting in recent years and he' expressed the
hope that the idea will be perpetuated.
"I am convinced," he commented,"that there are mutual problems that can serve as a meeting ground for the faculty and student body. The most important of these is the status of the
Honor System on this campus."
The original impetus for the
meeting was supplied by discussions conducted during two meetings of student activities leaders,
held last semester, under the
auspices of Dean Shaffer and Dr.
W. Kelso Morrill, Director of
Student Activities.
"We have been discussing the
Honor System quite actively in
Omicron Delta Kappa meetings,
In the pages of News-Letter, and
at informal bull sessions since the
beginning of the year," Epstein
said, "and are now hoping that
some of the faculty will join us in
searching for a solution to the
problem."
"We are also using this problem
as a means toward establishing
some sort of mechanism for bringing the student and the faculty
member together on terms a little
more intimate than the class
room," he added.
The faculty members include:
Dr. W. Kelso Morrill, Dr. Thomas
Hubbard, Dr. Walter Boyer, Dr.
Rob Roy, Dr. Malcolm Moos, Dr.
Hans Gatzke, Dr. Clatence Long,
Dr. Eliot Stellar, Dr. John Gryder, Dr. H. Bentley Glass, Dr.
William McElroy, Dean G. Wilson
Shaffer, and Dr. Francis Carlson.
The students are: Eugene Sekulow, Alvin Deutsch, Al N. Epstein,
Craig Haight, Angelo Fortunato,
Simeon Margolis, Eugene Zemsky,
Ned Howell, Frank P. L. Somerville, Rudy Lerner, Arthur Sarnoff,
Edward Chvatal and Ross Jones.
The meeting and a buffet supper
will be served and will begin at
5:30 p.m.

MASTER

The extemporaneous speaking
contest was won by Robert Stanton of St. Peters College. Second
place was won by James Robinson
of George Washington, while
third place was taken by Cadet
R. P. Morris of the United States
Military Academy. Plaques were
awarded to the three.
The tournament, directed by
Charles E. Moylan, Jr., President
of the Hopkins Debate Council,
was culminated by a banquet
Saturday night. Princeton was
given a permanent trophy and
possession of the rotating trophy
it won last year. George Washington received the second place
permanent trophy, and Howard
University, third place.

or the University of Southern California.

FULL TIME—from June, 1953 to Sept., 1953.
HALFTIME—from Sept., 1953 to June, 1954.
FULL TIME—from June, 1954 to Sept., 1954.
HALF TIME—from Sept., 1954 to June, 1955.

normal salary each year and attend a

In the predawn of last July 21, the most
severe California earthquake since 1906 struck
the small town of Tehachapi.
Walls were collapsing, buildings were folding. The town's telephone office shook to its
foundation. But the night operator remained
at her switchboard until it went dead. Main
cables to the office were pulled to the ground
when a nearby wall caved in.
This was at 4:50 A.M.
By 8:30 A.M. telephones were set up on the
edge of town for use by the Red Cross and
other emergency workers.
By late afternoon, the telephone switchboard was working. Tehachapi residents were
able to contact friends and relatives concerned
about their safety.

By 9 P.M. two TV stations were sending live
telecasts of the damage. Telephone men had
established a radio-relay system in less than
12 hours.
•
It was a typical disaster—brutal and unannounced. But telephone men were prepared.
They quickly restored comlnunication when
it was needed most. They demonstrated the
resourcefulness and technical skill typical of
telephone people.
These are some of the qualities we seek in
the college graduates we hire. Your Placement Officer can give you details about opportunities for employment in the Bell System.
Or write to American Telephone and Telegraph Company, College Relations Section,
195 Broadway, New York 7, New York, for
the booklet, "Looking Ahead."

NEWS-LETTER

Homewood, Baltimore, February 13, 1953

Student - Facu:ty Group To Meet;
Bulletin
Board
Honor System, Other Issues Aired
In order to stimulate more effective discussion of mutual problems, a group of students and
faculty members will meet informally this evening in the Sherwood Room.
"I am hoping that the Honor System will be discussed," Al Epstein, chairman of the student group, said early this week.
Twenty-six persons have been invited to attend; thirteen faculty members and an equal number of "responsible" students.
Epstein reminded that this is the first such meeting in recent years and he' expressed the
hope that the idea will be perpetuated.
"I am convinced," he commented,"that there are mutual problems that can serve as a meeting ground for the faculty and student body. The most important of these is the status of the
Honor System on this campus."
The original impetus for the
meeting was supplied by discussions conducted during two meetings of student activities leaders,
held last semester, under the
auspices of Dean Shaffer and Dr.
W. Kelso Morrill, Director of
Student Activities.
"We have been discussing the
Honor System quite actively in
Omicron Delta Kappa meetings,
In the pages of News-Letter, and
at informal bull sessions since the
beginning of the year," Epstein
said, "and are now hoping that
some of the faculty will join us in
searching for a solution to the
problem."
"We are also using this problem
as a means toward establishing
some sort of mechanism for bringing the student and the faculty
member together on terms a little
more intimate than the class
room," he added.
The faculty members include:
Dr. W. Kelso Morrill, Dr. Thomas
Hubbard, Dr. Walter Boyer, Dr.
Rob Roy, Dr. Malcolm Moos, Dr.
Hans Gatzke, Dr. Clatence Long,
Dr. Eliot Stellar, Dr. John Gryder, Dr. H. Bentley Glass, Dr.
William McElroy, Dean G. Wilson
Shaffer, and Dr. Francis Carlson.
The students are: Eugene Sekulow, Alvin Deutsch, Al N. Epstein,
Craig Haight, Angelo Fortunato,
Simeon Margolis, Eugene Zemsky,
Ned Howell, Frank P. L. Somerville, Rudy Lerner, Arthur Sarnoff,
Edward Chvatal and Ross Jones.
The meeting and a buffet supper
will be served and will begin at
5:30 p.m.

In the predawn of last July 21, the most
severe California earthquake since 1906 struck
the small town of Tehachapi.
Walls were collapsing, buildings were folding. The town's telephone office shook to its
foundation. But the night operator remained
at her switchboard until it went dead. Main
cables to the office were pulled to the ground
when a nearby wall caved in.
This was at 4:50 A.M.
By 8:30 A.M. telephones were set up on the
edge of town for use by the Red Cross and
other emergency workers.
By late afternoon, the telephone switchboard was working. Tehachapi residents were
able to contact friends and relatives concerned
about their safety.

By 9 P.M. two TV stations were sending live
telecasts of the damage. Telephone men had
established a radio-relay system in less than
12 hours.
•
It was a typical disaster—brutal and unannounced. But telephone men were prepared.
They quickly restored comlnunication when
it was needed most. They demonstrated the
resourcefulness and technical skill typical of
telephone people.
These are some of the qualities we seek in
the college graduates we hire. Your Placement Officer can give you details about opportunities for employment in the Bell System.
Or write to American Telephone and Telegraph Company, College Relations Section,
195 Broadway, New York 7, New York, for
the booklet, "Looking Ahead."
